deliberation: Checked the chronological and historical markers, which are literal. Detected (1) the idiomatic anthropomorphic phrase 'the hand of YHWH was upon me' as a conventional metaphor for prophetic seizure, and (2) 'the city was struck' as a metonymic way of referring to the city's destruction and its inhabitants' suffering. No hyperbole, irony, or similes present.

target: Ezekiel’s experience of prophetic seizure and empowerment
vehicle: a physical hand exerting force or control on a body
ground: the exercise of overwhelming power and control initiating an action
effect of a strong grasp on a passive recipient
agency and causation
posture: Ezekiel portrayed as passive under overpowering divine initiative
subjection to a superior will
authoritative divine control over the prophet’s movements
instances.explanation: The anthropomorphic idiom ‘the hand of YHWH was upon me’ metaphorically depicts God’s overpowering influence and control as a physical hand seizing a person, a standard prophetic expression for inspiration or compulsion.

instances.english_text: the fourteenth year after the city had [been] struck / fallen
target: the destruction/conquest of Jerusalem and its inhabitants
vehicle: ‘the city’ as something that is struck
the urban entity as a single object receiving a blow
ground: the fate of the inhabitants and structures is represented by the city as a whole
container standing for what it contains
metonymic representation of a collective by its locale
posture: compresses complex suffering and judgment into a single event term
gives a unified perspective on the city’s fall
frames history as a decisive blow under divine sovereignty
instances.explanation: ‘The city was struck’ uses ‘city’ metonymically for the whole population and infrastructure that underwent destruction, collapsing a complex siege into the image of a single blow.

deliberation: Considered whether the high mountain and city outline are symbolic; linguistically they are straightforward elements of the vision. The phrase 'in visions of God' is a standard prophetic formula for revelation, functioning idiomatically to denote divinely granted visions rather than ordinary sight. No similes, personifications, or hyperbole detected.

instances.english_text: It brought me, in divine visions,
vehicle: ‘visions of God’ as a technical description
a special class of visions associated with God as source
ground: the content and origin of these visions are uniquely divine, not ordinary perception
visions marked off as authoritative and supernatural
distinction between mundane and revelatory experience
posture: presents Ezekiel as a seer transported within God-given visions
underscores his passivity and God’s initiative
claims revelatory authority for what is described
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘in visions of God’ is an idiomatic prophetic formula marking a special, divinely sourced visionary state, differentiating it from normal seeing.

deliberation: The description is mostly literal (a figure with measuring tools). The explicit comparison 'his appearance like the appearance of bronze' is a clear simile, using metallic imagery to convey radiance or strength. No other figurative devices detected.

instances.english_text: a figure who shone like copper / whose appearance was like the appearance of bronze
target: the visual impression of the mysterious ‘man’ (angelic figure)
ground: brightness, gleam, and perhaps hardness or majesty common to both
striking visual radiance
sensory similarity
posture: Ezekiel uses familiar sensory imagery to approximate an ineffable sight
acknowledges limits of human description
adopts an analogical, not literal, mode of portrayal
instances.explanation: The comparison ‘his appearance like the appearance of bronze’ is a simile, using bronze’s shine and solidity to convey the dazzling, awe‑inspiring look of the heavenly figure.

deliberation: The verse mixes literal imperatives (look, listen) with several conventional figurative expressions: (1) the vocative 'son of man' as an idiomatic, metonymic way to address Ezekiel as a mere mortal; (2) 'set your heart' for concentrating one’s attention; and (3) 'house of Israel' as a metonymy for the people. These are standard Hebrew figures, not architectural.

ground: emphasizes Ezekiel’s membership in frail humanity as contrasted with the divine speaker
stresses weakness and limitation
creator–creature distinction
posture: positions Ezekiel as humble, finite recipient of revelation
heightens the asymmetry between God and prophet
encourages reverent attentiveness
instances.explanation: The address ‘son of man’ is an idiomatic, metonymic way to say ‘human one’, underlining Ezekiel’s mortality and lowliness over against God.

instances.hebrew_text: וְשִׂ֣ים לִבְּךָ֗ לְכֹ֤ל אֲשֶׁר־אֲנִי֙ מַרְאֶ֣ה אוֹתָ֔ךְ
instances.english_text: and set your heart to everything that I am going to show you
vehicle: ‘setting’ or placing the heart toward an object
moving/positioning a physical organ or object
ground: directing attention likened to physically positioning the core of one’s being
intentional orientation toward something
attention-as-orientation metaphor
posture: presents attention as an active, volitional stance Ezekiel must take
invites whole‑hearted engagement with revelation
frames listening as a disciplined inner posture
instances.explanation: ‘Set your heart’ is an idiomatic metaphor portraying mental focus and receptivity as if one were physically placing or directing the heart toward what God reveals.

target: the people of Israel as a nation
vehicle: ‘house’ as a single household or dynasty
ground: a nation conceptualized as one extended household descended from a common ancestor
unity and kinship bonds
container/structure representing its members
posture: frames Israel as a family under God’s authority
invokes covenantal household imagery
highlights corporate responsibility to heed the vision
instances.explanation: ‘House of Israel’ uses ‘house’ metonymically for the entire people, viewing the nation as one familial household descended from Israel/Jacob.

deliberation: The verse gives technical measurements of a wall and the measuring rod. Repetition of ‘all around’ is spatial, not rhetorical hyperbole in context. No metaphors, similes, idioms, or metonymies beyond literal architectural description are present.

This is a straightforward description of approaching the east-facing gate and measuring its threshold. The language is concrete and architectural; directional terms and measurement units are literal. No figurative expressions detected.

The verse continues precise measurements of recesses, distances, and thresholds. All terms function in a technical, spatial sense; there is no metaphorical use of body parts, no similes, and no idioms.
Only a literal measurement of the inner vestibule of the gate is given. No evaluative or figurative language is used.
Again, this is purely architectural description: cubit counts for vestibule and supports, with a note on location. No imagery, idiom, or non-literal usage appears.
Describes the number and identical size of recesses and supports at the eastern gate. The comparison ‘one measure’ is numerical, not figurative. No metaphor or idiom is present.
Contains only straightforward measurements of width and length of the gate opening. No figurative constructions appear.
The ‘barriers’ and distances are literal architectural features. No metaphorical use of ‘boundary’ or similar terms is evident in this technical context.
The measuring from roof to roof and the phrase ‘opening opposite opening’ are literal spatial descriptions of facing recesses across a passage. No figurative senses detected.
Refers to constructing and measuring supports (’elim) and their relationship to the court. These are structural terms used literally. No figurative language present.
States the quantitative distance from the outer gate’s front to the inner vestibule. This is a simple spatial measure without figurative overlay.

Describes windows, frames, and palm decorations on supports and vestibules. ‘Palms’ refers to carved or sculpted motifs, which, though symbolically rich, are here described literally as ornamentation. No explicit figurative phrasing within the verse.
Mentions being brought to the outer court, with chambers and pavement all around, and the number of chambers. The language is entirely descriptive and technical; no metaphor or idiom is used.
The pavements ‘flanking’ the gates and corresponding in length are literal spatial relations. No figurative extension of these terms is present.
Reports a 100-cubit measurement between gates at specific orientations (east, north). All terms are spatial and numeric; there is no figurative or idiomatic use.
Simply notes a north-facing gate of the outer court and measuring its length and width. No figurative language involved.
Lists the three recesses, supports, vestibule, and dimensions mirroring the first gate. The comparisons are factual equivalences, not literary similes or metaphors.

Windows, vestibule, and palm trees are said to correspond to those of the east gate, and the number of steps is given. This is descriptive, not figurative; palms refer to decorations, not metaphorical ‘palms’.
States that a gate of the inner court faces the north and east gates, and that the distance from gate to gate is 100 cubits. No figurative expressions are used.
Describes movement to the south side, finding a gate, and measuring its supports and vestibule ‘according to these measures’. All terms are literal and technical.

Notes that this gate and its vestibule have windows like the others and gives its dimensions. The likeness is an architectural correspondence, not a simile used for imagery. No figurative language detected.
The seven steps, the position of the vestibule, and palm-tree decorations on supports are literal structural and decorative details. No metaphorical deployment of these terms within the verse.
Gives the existence of an inner-court gate facing south and a 100‑cubit distance between gates. All language is spatially literal.
Entrance to the inner court through the south gate and measurement ‘according to these measures’ continue the technical description. No figurative devices appear.
Enumerates recesses, supports, vestibule, and repeated reference to windows and size. This is purely architectural specification with no imagery beyond literal forms.
States dimensions of vestibules on both sides. No metaphor, idiom, or personification is present.
Speaks of the vestibule opening to the outer court, palms on supports, and an eight-step staircase. The terms function strictly as structural descriptors.
Mentions movement to the east side of the inner court and measuring the gate according to prior measures. No figurative language is used.
Repeats the pattern of recesses, supports, vestibule, windows, and measurements for another gate. The language is technical and literal.
Describes a vestibule opening to the outer court, palm-decorated supports, and eight steps. Although palms have symbolic resonance, the wording is literal description of ornament and stairs.
States that he was led to the north gate and measurements matched the others. This is straightforward architectural detail without figurative elements.
Lists recesses, supports, vestibule, windows, and size again. No non-literal language is present.
Mentions supports toward the outer court, palms on supports, and eight steps. All these are literal features; there is no linguistic metaphor or idiom indicated.
References a chamber with its entrance by the gate-supports, where burnt offerings are washed. The washing of the burnt offering is a ritual procedure described literally, not metaphorically.
Describes two tables on each side in the gate vestibule for slaughtering specific sacrifices. All terms (burnt offering, sin offering, guilt offering) function literally as cultic categories.
Continues enumerating the positions and number of tables near the north gate. The spatial prepositions and nouns are literal; no figurative language is employed.
Summarizes the number of tables on each flank and their purpose for slaughter. This counting and functional description is literal, with no metaphor or idiom.
Gives dimensions and material of stone tables and their use for placing instruments of sacrifice. All vocabulary is concrete and ritual-technical.

Mentions shelves (or hooks) of a handbreadth and sacrificial flesh on the tables. The ‘handbreadth’ is a standard unit, not a metaphor, and ‘flesh’ is literal sacrificial meat. No figurative language apparent.

Describes chambers for singers with specified positions and orientations. ‘Singers’ are literal temple personnel. Directions (north, south) are spatial. No metaphors, idioms, or personifications used.

Identifies one chamber as for priests who ‘keep the charge of the house’. The phrase ‘keep the charge’ (shomrê mishmeret) is a conventional idiom portraying priestly duty as guarding or keeping custody, thus a mild conceptual metaphor. No other figures detected.

instances.english_text: for the priests who perform the duties of / keep the charge of the temple
target: priests’ responsibility for temple service and order
vehicle: guarding or watching over something entrusted
ground: priestly functions conceptualized as guarding a trust or assignment
vigilance, faithfulness, and accountability
duty-as-trust metaphor
posture: presents priests as custodians rather than owners of the temple
emphasizes their accountability to a higher authority (God)
frames service as careful, protective stewardship
instances.explanation: The idiom ‘those who keep the charge of the house’ metaphorically portrays the priests’ duties as guarding and watching over a trust, not merely performing routine tasks.

deliberation: Two idiomatic expressions appear: (1) priests ‘keeping the charge of the altar’, parallel to v.45 and similarly metaphorical; and (2) the priests ‘who draw near to YHWH’ as a standard metaphor for privileged cultic access, conceptualized as physical proximity to a person of high status.

instances.english_text: for the priests who perform the duties of / keep the charge of the altar
target: priests’ specific responsibilities regarding the altar
vehicle: guarding or watching over an assigned object
ground: their service at the altar is treated as guarding and maintaining a sacred trust
stresses faithful oversight and protection
duty-as-entrusted-object metaphor
posture: depicts these priests as guardians of the altar’s sanctity
highlights their accountability for correct ritual practice
underscores the seriousness of their role
instances.explanation: As in v.45, ‘keeping the charge’ is an idiomatic metaphor, casting priestly altar service as the vigilant guarding of something entrusted, not just routine work.

instances.hebrew_text: הֵ֣מָּה בְנֵֽי־צָד֗וֹק הַקְּרֵבִ֧ים מִבְּנֵֽי־לֵוִ֛י אֶל־יְהֹוָ֖ה לְשָׁרְתֽוֹ
instances.english_text: they are the descendants of Zadok, who draw near to GOD to minister to Him
target: the Zadokite priests’ unique privilege of access and service to God
vehicle: physical movement into someone’s personal presence
ground: ritual and relational access to God conceived as bodily approach into His presence
closeness signifies privilege, intimacy, and honor
presence-as-space metaphor
posture: elevates Zadok’s descendants as intimate attendants of YHWH
marks a hierarchical distinction within Levi
reinforces reverent, service-oriented stance toward God
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘who draw near to YHWH’ is a metaphoric idiom where privileged cultic access is conceptualized as physical approach into God’s presence, signaling intimacy and high status.

deliberation: Reports the length and breadth of the court (100 by 100 cubits, ‘foursquare’) and notes the altar before the temple. ‘Foursquare’ here describes literal symmetry of dimensions, not perfection metaphorically. No figurative language is evident.
Details entry into the temple portico, measurements of jambs, and gate width. All terms are used in their literal architectural sense; no idioms or metaphors occur.
Gives the length and width of the portico, access by steps, and columns by the jambs. These are structural features, not images for other realities. No figurative language detected.
